description: From Middle English straught, from Old English streahte (first and third person singular preterite) and (ġe)streaht (past participle) of streċċan (“to stretch”). Doublet of straight. More at stretch.
From Scots straucht (“stretched, stretched out”). Compare Scots strauchten (“to straighten”).

adjectives.description: straught (comparative more straught, superlative most straught)

verbs.description: straught (third-person singular simple present straughts, present participle straughting, simple past and past participle straughted)

entries.meaning: (dialectal, chiefly Scotland) To stretch; make straight.

description: From apheresis of distraught, bestraught, forstraught, etc.

adjectives.description: straught (comparative more straught, superlative most straught)

examples: My ſcoles are not for unthriftes untaught,For frantick faitours half mad and half ſtraught;But my learning is of another degreeTo taunt theim like liddrons, lewde as thei bee.
